posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4413087
Most of the case is public, you can just look it up. He died from acute peritonitis due to his perforated colon. A perforated colon is very serious, but survival rates even for the time were quite generous. Peritonitis too is quite dangerous, but it mostly becomes a severe threat after a couple days, when sepsis and other problems make it essentially a death sentence. Obviously every case is different, but generally speaking someone with a perforated colon and acute peritonitis has around a 70% chance of complete recovery if they go to a hospital immediately. He waited days and sealed his fate (it also doesn't help that his "friends" just sort of threw his unconscious body on the ground outside the hospital when he was already half dead).
It wasn't his horse, but the owner was his friend who filmed the Mr Hands video. I don't know why the horse was upset, but that's the claim that was made in court, and given that this was apparently a routine activity for them without either of them being harmed (the horse owner is still fine to this day after having served 10 years in prison). So I don't know if animals "hate fuck" but something clearly was different in a bad way that night.

posts.com:
What actually stops fungi and other kingdoms from developing motile, macroscopic organisms? I am tired of only finding animals interesting. Fungi, at least, don't have rigid cell walls, so they should be able to move. There are, of course, also other macroscopic clades besides animals, plants, and fungi, e.g. the one that brown algae belong to, which are usually called "SAR", "Chromista", etc. These also could be possible areas where we could find a species that has 'moves like Jagger'.
>lack of a sophisticated nerve system
Doesn't stop jellyfish, comb jellies and other dimwit animals from being able to move.
(inb4 some midwit answers "at least they have one". Yes. The locomotory function necessitates a minimum nerve system, which such fungi would gain as a simple matter of consequence.)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Even if passively, everything is quite mobile. Seeds/spores move around using animals or the wind, or even the sea.
And I recall a lot of bacterium can actually move around, some in motor-like way, even.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4418132
Lot of people here massively underestimating the dynamism of plant root systems, not to mention the complete mobility of many fungus species.
Mycologists don't have to dig up an entire forest floor to find some kinds of fungi. They can set baits for them. The fungi "smell" the bait underground and literally grow towards it so they can consume it. Some even recycle their own arse end so they can grow quicker towards the bait.
Fungi build numerous different kinds of traps to catch nematode worms, freshwater plankton and other prey.
Look into this stuff. It's really fascinating.

>>4417426
If you get the fancy/deformed ones probably. On the lighter side this red one is albino, albinism means that it doesn't produce melanin but they still can have other pigments like the red pigment here (probably carotenoids). Balloon molly on the other hand is one with a fucked up spine. There is also the issues of generations of inbreeding so it would help if you get multiple starters preferably from different sources.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4417448
Now if I weren't such shrimp fan I would probably make a large planted tank with lots of molly fish. I heard that they are decent algae eaters so that would help the plants as well. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4417426
Platys don't, they've got some really weird genetic stuff going on naturally but nothing harmful, and because there are several different xiphophorus sp. that hybridize regularly at this point, they're much hardier than guppies or mollies (though the latter are mostly fine, outside of Ballon ones, they just very big compared to the others)

Do not keep guppies and mollies together, they will cross breed and it kills the female guppies 100% of the time because of the size difference. You can mix and match xiphophorus to your hearts content, though if you get wild types and mix them with domestics, you'll make the crying Indian sad or something.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4417460
female mollies can be mixed with guppies freely though and will help reduce the baby guppy swarms a little. And you might get a muppy.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4417698
Yes. I would advise putting separate color spectrum lightstrips on independent potentiometers so you can adjust each light channel to your liking. If you want to get fancy, you could use a microcontroller and digital pots to have fade-in/fade-out on a timer.

Also, higher CRI does make a bit of an aesthetic difference, so back when I made these things I didn't get the most expensive stuff, I also didn't get the super bargin bin Chinesium stuff. I also undervolted them a bit and it greatly increased lifespan. I considered wiring in some active cooling but I ended up breaking down that tank and now my only two tanks left have higher end lights.

I'm not even sure if sure if this project belongs in /aqg/ since this is gonna be an outdoor setup and technically a "micro pond" (I picked up a food safe 30G tub today and drew up plans for a wooden shell/stand) but I plan to use my knowledge from what my dad taught me and what I learned over my years from indoor aquarium keeping as a general guideline. I already spoke with my LFS and they said they would take Medaka juveniles off my hands, I plan to use them as test bed to see how quickly they sell there, if they just give me store credit or even if they just take them off my hands and tell me if they sell out quickly i'll be happy. From there depending on how well it goes I'll invest in a more fancy line beside the pearl galaxy.

I saw a bear for the first time a few months ago while I was hiking in bulgaria.
I was sitting down on the side of a road for a rest, not making any noise, when I heard huffing and puffing coming towards me. I thought it was a jogger at first and didn't look up from my phone, then I heard rustling in the raspberry bushes and I thought what is this guy doing, so I looked and I saw a big round brown hairy thing behind the bush in front of me, maybe 20 meters away...
I got up to move away and it finally heard me. It stood up too, took one look at me and fled into the forest.

That was cool.

Although it does make me wonder, could pandas adapt to another diet? I don't think there's anything about their digestion that says they absolutely HAVE to eat bamboo, it's essentially the same as other bears other than some microbial adaptations to make digesting bamboo easier.

I read they lost their sense of umami taste which is why they shunned meat (though they have occasionally been observed eating it in the wild) but I know they feed them other kinds of foods in zoos. If a panda was dropped in a place with abundant plant matter, would it eat them or is their instinct to eat bamboo so strong they would just starve? If so could captive pandas be trained to eat other foods then be released into the wild and carry on the behaviour?

>>4417092
Most of the slower growing more arid new world species are supposed to tolerate it pretty well, basically your Aphonopelma, Grammostola and Brachypelma and probably some of the less common genera from similar climates. That said, you always want to do it as close to the ground as possible because they're extremely fragile and you also want to make sure to check the temperament before you try to handle by gently touching the animal with a brush or something.

Overall I'd still recommend against it though, the animal gets nothing out of it and there's always a pretty significant risk of killing it if anything goes wrong

I believe large dinos had sparse feathers for cooling like how elephants hair actually improves cooling instead of keeping them warm. So small dinos will need mechanisms to keep themselves warm enough while big ones will need mechanisms to irradiate heat.

From what I know the most up to date version of Ggiganotosaurus skull reconstruction is as >>4411960 posted but if you wanna know which skull reconstruction is incorrect you need to see the nasal bone and the inferior temporal fenestra. Pic related is a incorrect reconstruction with the inferior temporal fenestra being way too wide and exaggerated making the skull a lot longer than it is supposed to be which the OP's artist mistakenly has drawn. There's also the nasal part of the skull which is usually drawn flat like an acrocanthosaurus (or like the JW:D Giga).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4412802
In dinosaurs it's never right to refer to the infratemporal fenestra as the inferior temporal fenestra because dinosaurs are generally described as having 3 temporal fenestrae rather than 2. The inferior temporal fenestra would be the subtemporal fenestra, not the infratemporal.

also you can't know if the infratemporal fenestra is drawn too wide because those bones haven't been found.

A couple thoughts:
We don't actually use the size or shape of the ITF or any cranial fenestra to ID dinosaurs because the size and shape varied between species, between individuals of the same species, and even between the two sides of the skull in individuals.
We don't use skull shape to ID dinosaurs for the same reasons, too much variation within the species.

similarly, the fenestra aren't described as being the wrong shape or size, we would rather say, e.g., the top illustration restores the lower (ventral) body (or bar) of the quadratojugal twice as long as suggested by comparison to other related taxa.

This doesn't necessarily make it wrong. A much longer quadratojugal might be normal for the species, we don't know because we haven't found one. Or it could be because of individual variation.

Because of this, there's no "correct" or "incorrect" restoration as long as they both fit the known elements of the skull.

Your lower pic is incorrect because it does not fit the known elements of the skull. Basically the artist appears to have substituted the braincase of Carcharodontosaurus into the skull even though the braincase of giga is known, and is much different in shape and proportions.

In their description of the braincase, Coria and Currie state, "the distal extremities of the parasphenoid-basisphenoid, paroccipital processes, and basioccipital had been destroyed beofore the specimen was discovered."
However examination of the landmarks of the braincase, including things like depth of the pituitary fossa, angle of the interorbital septum, and angle and height of the opisthotic at the base of the paroccipital process, indicate that the braincase didn't undergo huge distortion due to diagenesis, and the height is not more than ~15% reduced by loss of the basioccipital etc.

What all this means, is the braincase doesn't fit into the restoration correctly. Picrel is closer to what it would look like proportioned right.

I should also point out that all of these skull oddities, such as skull length vs skull height, angle of the occiput, and sloping of the posterior skull roof,
have been suggested to be size-related by several scientists, including me.

It's possible that these shapes aren't so much a matter of evolution, but of ontogeny. They seem to be common to lots of gigantic theropods, even if they all evolved slightly different ways of producing the same shapes.

and these shapes may not be present in juveniles or smaller adults. If they're size related, the skull took on a different shape as the animal grew. This idea is supported by two lines of evidence, the first being just a simple survey of skull shapes in large and small theropods. The other being the fact that the bones of the braincase fused fairly early in theropod life, making them grow much more slowly than other skull bones.

and when the back of your skull stops growing but the front doubles in size, you're going to wind up with roughly the same skull shapes associated with the same size skulls every time.

basically babby giga may have looked a lot different from grown-up giga.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4414466
>the bones of the braincase fused fairly early in theropod life, making them grow much more slowly than other skull bones.
So basically the back of the skull slowed its growth at adulthood while the bones of the face kept right on growing at full speed.

some animals (Allosaurus) apparently never fully fused the bones of the face. Others fused much later in life than adulthood. So either way, we get a pattern where as theropods got larger the back of the skull tended to get longer, lower, and more vertical. The rest of the face is attached to the back of the skull so it may have gotten longer and lower as the animal grew as well. Or developed a slope at the back of the skull changing the angles of the back of the skull.

only time will tell if this is fact or not, but either way we see some of the same shapes evolving different ways in the skulls of all gigantic theropods.

Nobody reads de Ricqlès work on bone histology anymore.

so here's the problem. Bone isn't really living tissue, it can't grow. How it 'grows' in long bones anyways is the inside is dissolved by the body (resorbed) and a new layer is added to the outside.

what this means is that growth rings on the inside are steadily being destroyed as new ones are added to the outside. Meaning most of the growth rings in dinosaur bones are missing.

This should be obvious to anyone, as dinosaurs were born with bones a few mm in diameter and died with ones several cm in inside diameter, meaning every growth ring from hatching right up to that several cm inside diameter was erased.

Apparently this isn't widely known by paleontologists anymore so we get stupid stuff like adult T. rex being 19 years old when it very likely is closer to 75. But what are you gonna do? >>4415912
It's complicated, but I was talking about the ~80% of cortical bone mass in long bones that's not technically alive. The portion paleontologists generally (but not always) use to estimate dinosaur growth.

Other bones are much more 'alive' in the sense that they're remodeled constantly from within the cortex and are even less useful for measuring growth because of this.

Also how bones grow and stop growing varies in different animals. The process I describe for long bones is generally true for the shaft of the bone across most vertebrates, but how long bone ends grow and then stop growing varies in reptiles, mammals, and birds. These differences give us clues to growth over time in dinosaurs. For example, both mammals and birds have different mechanisms to stop bones from growing once they reach adult sizes. Extinct dinosaurs lacked these mechanisms, perhaps indicating they didn't stop growing as long as they were alive.
iirc some fish have a mix of birdlike and mammallike mechanisms to arrest bone growth at a certain adult size.

I'm not an expert on bone histology though, I read it but I don't claim to know everything there is to know about it. Just enough to see the problems with say, using long bone growth rings to estimate age or growth rates in an animal with hollow bones. Or to see the fallacy in assuming dinosaurs had an adult size when their bones have no apparent mechanism to stop growing.

>>4416005
Growth rings weren't initially examined as a method of aging dinosaurs, no zoologist I know of considers them reliable in modern species, let alone extinct ones we know little about.

The problem is growth rings indicate the animal is cold blooded or goes through seasonal times of reduced food availability or extreme cold that arrest bone growth.

Most paleontologists believe gigantic theropods were either warm blooded or mass homeotherms, and this is supported by the fact that say, some T. rex have growth rings while others do not. Or some bones in one T. rex may have growth rings while others do not. Or some bones in T. rex have some growth rings while other bones on the other side of the body have a different number.

They're not great evidence for cold bloodedness to begin with, and you'd have to assume that the animal is cold blooded and the growth rings prove it in order to trust them to age even the parts of the bone that have rings. Or that the animal faced seasonal food shortages or extreme cold, which again point to ectothermy.

None of these assumptions are well-supported, and none of them is universally accepted. In fact most paleontologists believe the opposite.

>>4416659

I don't care about any of this other shit with wattles or whatever, that's pretty clearly speculative and I can take it or leave it - many modern reptiles are covered in wattles and dewlaps, as are many modern birds.
But your statement that 'reptiles basically can't be fat' when they specifically store adipose tissue in abdominal fat bodies and in their tail is just wrong/retarded and a product of your biased hysterical overreaction to some paleoart you don't like. There isn't a fundamental biological rule that states that 'reptiles don't have fat', because, conversely, they do. They don't have the same level of extensive fat deposits that mammals have because A) modern reptiles are generally smaller so require less on demand energy and B) surviving reptile taxa are all ectotherms, meaning they can't survive on burning their own calories alone, they need to warm themselves with the sun. Most of their fat deposits are for reproductive purposes primarily. However, we now know it's unlikely that a purely ectothermic regulation method could've supported the metabolic rates of most dinosaurs, which were generally larger than modern reptiles, more active, and grew a lot faster. They had four-chambered hearts (all modern reptiles except for crocodiles have 3 chambers, crocodiles require 4 chambers because they are aquatic and probably inherited it from archosaur ancestors), likely a sustained aerobic metabolism (indicated by chambered air sacs), and ecologies that do not reflect ectothermic lifestyles (the ratio of the total mass of predators to prey in dinosaur communities was much more like that of modern and recent warm-blooded communities than that of recent or fossil cold-blooded communities.)
They were either wholly warm-blooded endotherms like their modern bird descendants, or they had intermediate mesotherm metabolisms somewhere between full ectothermy or full endothermy, perhaps with different lineages covering different types of metabolism.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4416659
>>4416761

Whatever the combination, the evidence shows that many dinosaurs were homeotherms and could independently maintain body temperature and metabolism in a way that modern reptiles can't. Now, if they were indeed endotherms, then they might have a different relationship with their adipose deposits than modern reptiles do, ie they might require them to maintain a high metabolic rate.
You don't have to undo the entire Dinosaur Renaissance just because you hate modern paleoart. It's very much the case that there's a lot of retarded stuff out there but that doesn't bring us back to the conclusion that dinosaurs were just 'muh big lizards'. They were a lineage of reptiles that developed a collection of traits that made them wholly different from other reptile groups, including modern taxa. That's why they were so SUCCESSFUL for 165 million years, because these adaptions allowed them to dominate Triassic ecosystems in a way that other archosaurs or lepidosaurs or just other diapsid reptiles weren't capable of doing. Which is why their only surviving descendants, birds, are so totally different from any other line of reptiles.
Just admit this modern paleoart rubs you up the wrong way because you think it looks retarded. There's no shame in that, I'd agree with you on a lot of it. But that doesn't justify trying to ignore some of the very unique things we know about dinosaurs that means that modern reptiles are NOT a good analogue for reconstructions, in much the same way that modern birds or, even further afield, mammals are also not a good analogue. Dinosaurs, as a lineage, were entirely sui generis and their only surviving non-avian reptile relatives are highly specialised aquatic predators that are very different from what we know about dinosaurs. With regards to other modern reptile groups, like squamates and testudines, they aren't all that helpful in understanding dinosaurs because they differ in fundamental ways.

What's the ancestral condition? Small enough to fly, or at least glide? In that case flight-like feathers seem at least somewhat plausible as a retained feature. Ostriches don't have flight feathers per se but they have some feathers which look 'feathery' rather than 'hairy'.
Also, I think it's just about possible that a lot of dinosaurs weren't capable of true flight but benefited from improved aerodynamics in terms of being able to make extended jumps or survive falls. In terms of coolness, I'm not convinced that hair-like feathers as seen in kiwis, cassowaries, etc. actually looks less silly than flight feathers. At least flight (style) feathers in eagle-colours look like a serious predator we are familiar with.

It isn't synonymous with genus Vulpes, as you seem to be implying. A "fox" is simply a medium-sized wild canid with a long bushy tail, pointed ears, and usually slit pupils. Some foxes belong to genus Vulpes, while others do not.

It's the same with "bugs". Did you know that only insects in order Hemiptera are classified as "true bugs"? Yet I'm sure none of y'all here are pedantic enough to only call Hemipterans bugs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Foxes also have a little cleft under their nose that's usually closed, but when they yawn it spreads open (pic). Imagine being 1mm tall and being stuck inside that little cleft haha

Also there's 4 types of whisker:
- mystacial (the obvious ones), supraorbital (above the eye), genal (cheeks), and mandibular (bottom of jaw).

The mystacial whiskers are further grouped into macro- and microvibrissae. Macro are the big long whiskers, micro are the short small whiskers above the lips.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4415206
Humans' body stink is unintended and a consequence of poor hygiene (btw you missed stinky breath). Thus from an early age we condition ourselves to associate body stink with "bad".

But in foxes, their smell is NOT due to poor hygiene, but rather intentionally produced by specialized glands because it's tool for communication and helping foxes find one another in the wild.

If we realize this, that's it's not a bad-hygiene smell, then we can start to work on overriding our assumptions and learning to see fox smell as pleasant. Fox smell means a fox is nearby, and that's good news, because foxes are beautiful and bring joy to the mind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4415258
Humans don't have to be conditioned to want to bathe. It's an evolved response to encourage parasite removal and prevention of fungal skin infections, and encourages you to avoid creatures that could spread parasites and diseases that are already adapted to primates (ie: chimps). People who LIKE their stink are less fit for survival. There are human smells that do serve a behavioral function but you don't even perceive them as a smell, and they're in sweat in general, not just the festering bacteria laden stuff that hangs out in crevices and creates the odor that drives people to bathe. You're not conscious of it, you just feel a certain way within noseshot for certain people.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4416439
The most beautiful sight to a fox is another fox, so at least we have that in common.

>Do they normally move into their dens when the vixens get pregnant, or not until the kits are about to be born?
For 'single' foxes, a tod patrols 'his' scent-marked territory and when a vixen wanders into it during breeding season he'll find her via her calls and scent and they'll mate, then after mating the vixen follows the tod and they stay together from then on in the male's territory. Both tod and vixen find an appropriate place and dig the den together while she's pregnant, then the vixen moves into the den (alone) when she's ready to give birth. While she nurses the young inside the den the male will be out hunting to bring home prey for her and the young. When not hunting, he'll be guarding the den from outside. He rarely enters the den.

For already mated pairs, they'll reuse their den from last year (cleaning it out first and adding new escape tunnels) or make a new one if they find a better spot. Widowed foxes will find a new mate and the female will join the male's territory. A family of foxes will stay loosely together until the next mating season starts to come near, at which time the parents will drive away their remainig kids so they can go establish their own territories. Though sons always leave their parents, sometimes daughters won't mate and will continue to live near their parents, sometimes helping them raise their next litter.

Oh, and biologically-related foxes can be friendly and have dens next to each other, there's a cute photo series of two fox familes who live together here: here https://dakotareflections.com/dakota%20region/red%20fox.html

>>4416847
Thanks, that's a good demo. Small foxes' camoflage is to protect them from predators like eagles, whereas large foxes' camoflage is to stay hidden from their prey. Seeing a fennec from an eagle's eye view would be even harder than from the side because they're especially sand-colored on the top. The effort to stay invisible from their predators, as well as their prey, has evolutionarily shaped how foxes look.

posts.com:
Okay, since our friends from /pol/ produced nothing but inane ramblings (as expected) let me give you some historical context.
Fair warning to the aforementioned /pol/acks – this is not going to be one of your meme pictures you use to “redpill” each other.
There will be a shitton of words words words, so you better leave right now since you don’t give a fuck about dogs, or truth in general.

Here we go
Back in ye olden days word "borzoi" was used to refer to any breed of sighthounds, and the specific borzoi breed of today would be called Russkaya psovaya borzaya,
or Russian silky\wavy sighthound (because of their long and soft coat).

For at least five centuries Russian nobility used borzoi dogs to hunt local wildlife.
And if in sixteenth century most nobles were living in the countryside, along with their people (but in manors instead of huts) and reasonably-sized packs of dogs that they genuinely cared about, and hunted with. In eighteenth-nineteenth centuries they mostly relocated to St. Petersburg and other cities, their lifestyle changed drastically, they were no longer living on the land they owned, the gap between them and their people grew larger and larger, along with their affinity for wealth and decadence.

Instead of having any kind of personal relationship with their dogs, they would employ various managers to build and maintain large kennels in their lands to compete with one another in “If Count Boris has 200 borzoi dogs, then I shall have 300!” meaningless displays of wealth. One of them (Samsonov of Smolensk) called himself “The Greatest Hunter” simply because his kennel had well over a thousand of dogs. This led to overbreeding and completely inadequate treatment of the aforementioned dogs. (More on that later). The only dogs that could truly be considered pets and companions at this point were the lucky ones that the owner of the kennel (or more likely his wife and children) picked during their rare visits to their owned lands.

"Hound hunting” turned into a bunch of rich city brats trotting along the road, talking about all the French thots they fucked on their last visit to Paris, while dozens (or even hundreds) of dogs with their hound masters would run around, chasing some poor fox (that was pre-captured, and then released specifically for the occasion, malnourished and weak).

More about mistreatment. It’s kinda hard to properly care for hundreds of dogs, when you are an illiterate 19th century fuck that never heard the words “cynology”, “zoology”, or even “biology”. Doing things “by heart” works when you only have a small number of dogs – but not on this industrial scale. Hence there were a lot of questionable practices, a number of fetishistic ones – some kennel masters forced young peasant mothers to nourish puppies, because human milk was supposed to “make them stronger” (but not cow or goat milk, obviously those wouldn’t work).

And some practices were downright abhorrent. For example, how do you train all of these dogs to hunt? They won’t get any better at chasing prey while howling in their cages, you DO have to set them loose somewhere, and you have two options.
First - the hard one, you can actually take them to the wild forests and fields of Russia, let them awaken their natural instincts by trying to chase and catch something out there. There is a considerable risk, however, of them running off and getting lost, despite your best efforts to control the pack.

And so, most kennel masters chose the second option, DO let them loose, but not in the wilds – right here, amongst the villages and crop fields. Let them trample the crops and chase after chickens, let them harass the peasants and their children. And if in a rare accident a borzoi strangles a peasant child to death – who cares? Serfs are much cheaper than puppies, so you warn them not to resist, or be lashed for daring to raise a hand against master’s dogs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Unsurprisingly, commoners had a problem with all of this, and many other things they experienced at the hands of their ‘betters’, since sometimes peasants were not “collateral damage” of borzoi hunting packs, but their actual intended targets, either for fun or to deal with a riot at hand. (The latter happened all the way to 1905 revolution)

When in 1861, after centuries of riots and bloodshed the serfdom was finally abolished, and Russian people got something that at least resembles human rights, two things happened that are largely the reason for the decline of borzoi population. First – your average aristocrat lost a considerable portion of their income, so no more frivolous activities like owning hundreds of dogs for hunting.

Second – the free peasants of Russia would no longer tolerate packs of hounds running around their villages, destroying crops, harassing livestock, posing threat to their children. They would take shovels, rakes and pitchforks and actively defend their livelihoods. This is mentioned by A. N. Engelhardt in his 1863 letter where he talks about the disappearance of hound hunting, saying that although conflicts between peasants and hunters/hound masters always did happen – usually the hunters would use the special horn they had to summon reinforcements and fuck up the peasant filth, but this approach no longer worked, too many peasants grew too bold to be bullied around. One such incident is depicted on a 1860s painting by Pyotr Sokolov (picrelated) - peasants assault hunters and their dogs, protecting their crops.

All of this happened long before Bolsheviks, when socialism in Russia was unheard of.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So, in the beginning of 20th century the population of borzoi was already well in decline, and the events that followed only accelerated said decline.

Russo-Japanese war, First World War, two Revolutions (three if you count the 1905 one) and a long Civil War – all of this took a toll on Russian population, and by extent – on their domesticated animals, but to say that there was some kind of a genocide perpetrated against this one breed because they were considered a symbol of aristocracy is ridiculous. Back then (during the Civil War) Bolsheviks had actual aristocrats and their armies to worry about.

And what about afterwards? Well, in 1930s the things calmed down (more or less) and in 1936 a Club for Borzoi Enthusiasts is registered under the All-Union Council of Physical Culture and Sports, so by that time there was a significant enough number of borzoi owners in the country for them to be recognized on a national level.

>>4397905
Big strong plant is mostly about getting enough light, water and warmth. As long as you fertilize at all it's usually enough. Slow release pellets are probably the easiest way. Or you could microdose fertilizer with every watering.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4397905
Most house plants are light starved and even if they get enough, you can still boost their growth with a longer photoperiod. 20h of light and a 4h night is ideal for building both size and plant mass. As for fertilizer, you should make sure they get enough Mg and Ca, as many fertilizers only have NPK. How much you fertilize is really not an exact science, you'll have to experiment. But most plants can take way more fertilizer than you think. Just make sure to water them with rainwater now and then to flush out all the excess salts. Airy substrate (perlite, bark, leca, etc are your friends) is a must so the roots don't rot. I'd look into what the hydroponics guys have written up on the net, they've got fertilizing down to a science.

>>4400045
Any Nepenthes hybrid with truncata in it. You're in the US, most likely? Presumptiously, here's a link to what you need https://www.carnivero.com/a/search?q=truncata&sort_by=price-ascending

(if you're an europoor like me, I recommend wistuba.com most highly)

Pick whichever one you like best. These will grow huge (talking a few feet across with foot tall pitchers, truncata hybrids regularly catch mice in greenhouses) and can take a beating. One with "veitchii" in it if you want it to withstand extra low humidity, but all of these will pitcher on the windowsill if you meet their light demands. Pot in airy substrate mix with perlite, pine bark and sphagnum moss. Fertilize by dumping fertilizer in the pitchers. Happy growing!

posts.com:
Would it be possible to grow Water Hyacinth in a hydro stone aquaponics system?

>But why?
I want to install a duck pond, with a filtering mechanism.
It pumps from the pond, to a solids filter, then to hydrostone bed which would grow duck feed.
Water Hyacinth propagate quickly so it makes good duck feed, but there needs to be a soilless media (Hydrostone or lava rocks) to act as a secondary filter before the water falls back into the pond.
>Why not grow the feed in the pond itself
The ducks would decimate it before it could grow to any decent size

Pic.
Doesn't frost here, "growing season" for annuals is reversed here too. Summer literally everything burns up, "winter" is when everything flowers and grows.

I was even considering beekeeping until I discovered that:
1. Western "beekeeper" bees literally cannot survive the summer. Most beekeepers drag their boxes to a cooler area up the mountains for 2 months per year.
2. Local wild bees only build open-air (i.e. you can't beekeep them), despite the inherent safety/security issues it's the ONLY way they can survive the insane temperatures

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4395462
Solution of neem oil, 2-3 drops of Dawn unscented dish soap, 1-2 drops of peppermint extract, water. Maybe 3 parts water for every 1 part neem oil. This solution is safe for pets, children, and basically anything that is not an insect. Begin byy spraying the mixed up solution into the soil until decently moist if not wet. Wait a week or so and see if populations have decreased. Repeat in soil weekly until they are gone. If the problem persists, purchase some plant dusting gloves and spray your hands with the solution, then wipe down the leaves. The undersides are most important.

I have successfully removed fungus gnats from my home 3-4 times using this method over the last decade or so.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4415734
Light is light. A tiny led is obviously nothing compared to a giant explosion in the sky, but situating it close enough to a leaf allows enough usable light particles to reach the plant and allow photosynthesis.
Vitamin d is matter of uv, and your plants don't want too much of it anyway, just like you, unless you're into cancer and blindness.
More serious led lights add some minimal uv leds of shallow almost visible specter to stimulate some specific fruiting and flowering plants.

in 2021 I've sown a wildflower meadow mix (annuals + perennials) into 50 square meters of cleared land (was a field of clovers and couch grass before) and a beautiful array of bachelor's buttons, poppies, echiums and borages emerged. This year I would like to go back to the explosion of colour I got with annuals 2 years ago so I'm planning to clear off the plot again and sow exclusively annuals.
I am aiming for that pastoral, idyllic look of hundreds of little flowers in every color and here are the species I'm planning to go with: Centaurea cyanus (bachelor's button), Papaver rhoeas (poppy), Agrostemma githago (corncockle) Consolida ajacis (larkspur), Vicia villosa (vetch), Glebionis segetum (corn daisy), Linum grandiflorum (red flax), Helinathus annus (sunflower), Echium plantagineum, Nigella arvensis (fennel flower) (sorry if common names are all fucked up, I'm an ESL and I've taken them from Wikipedia kek). posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4415339
With indoor plants, 95 per cent of it is getting enough light and water.
People struggle to grow big indoor plants like that big Monstera simply because they don't water them deeply. People don't want water running all over their floor, so they only put a little dribble of water on the top of the pot. Then the plants can only develop shallow roots and can't grow properly.
To get a nice, big, lush houseplant you need to water it regularly and deeply so that water comes pissing out of the holes in the bottom of the pot.
The only real way to do this is to take it outside on a trolley and water it with a hose (or to water it in the shower or bathtub, taking care not to block your drains with soil).
Re staking: Over time your little Monstera will grow towards its main light source, like pic related. You can minimise this by turning the pot 90 degrees every week or so.
When putting a stake in to hold it up, try to minimise the damage to the roots. Pick one place to put the stake in and just leave it there. If you keep pulling stakes out and pushing them back in you're just damaging more roots for no reason.
It looks like your Monstera is going really well so far. Well done!

>>4359128
Snowy owls are one of the few animals that unironically ignite my moé instincts. Not only do they look like adorable little angels, they also have the personalities of ones as well. Chick-on-chick infanticide is relatively rare in this species, and on top of that the siblings are known to share their given meals with each other. All the more impressive taking into consideration that they live in an environment that is only slightly more forgiving than the polar ice caps, or planet Hoth.

The species are sexually dimorphic to better suit their familial roles. The male is nearly solid white to blend into the tundra helping him to hide, but that also aids him in hunting lemmings. While the female is a speckled guardian who broods on a nest above permafrost, usually while tenderly pruning her offspring. However, like all parents the will fight beak and claw if any intruder ventures too close, from arctic foxes to polar bears, to the typical human.

If the don't melt your heart, I don't know what will.

>>4372256
That is an excellent question for multiple reasons:

1. It will be a fun project to reconstruct the vocal cords of this animal, there was even a YouTube video speculating on how T.Rex most likely sounded like a double bass, due to modern birds (of the large variety) using closed mouth vocals to communicate over a large distance, similar to elephants.

2. But on a more opinionated note. I find it disappointing that there was no grand designs towards this animal, and it reminds me of the enthusiastically, cheesy early iguanodon interpretations. It's better to imagine the creature as a 19th century Godzilla while being based on a single jawbone, rather than a lackluster paragraph on Wikipedia. Imagination is important to tell stories and to fill in the intellectual gaps, (as long as there is systematic evidence).

Crete is an underrated paleo landscape were big was small and vise versa, and it's eerie to think that the ancient Greeks noted the lack of hostile fauna of the island, and they all seemed to have disappeared like the Minoans.

>>4400543
If you want ducks, just handcatch them. Feed them, gain their trust. Give them bread, first some floating bits, when you have them within reach, squish the bread so that it sinks.

When they start diving for it, throw a few sinking pieces, grab them when they stick their heads under.

I used to do this to stop the ducks from trying to eat my fishing bait, just hold one (male for best results-) upside down for the rest to see. Then release, no problems for the rest of the day.

Or keep them, free pets/food.

I’ve owned like every breed of domestic duck and also some exotic ones like mandarins and wood ducks. Never had an issue with aggression. In domestic ducks drakes will only pick on other birds because they’re trying to rape them. They’re certainly a lot more docile to each other than chickens.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4400543
They have random personalities and males will fight like roosters will.
We have a male that was raised with chickens and he fucking despises our chickens and will chase them. Another male call duck is tiny as hell but will try and nip at your ankles. The rest are pretty chill.
Depending on the drake you will need 2-4 hens for him. Otherwise they will literally breed the poor females to death. Although sometimes you can get away with one to one ratios.
Call ducks especially pair off well, but don't like swimming like other ducks and prefer just to splash in shallow puddles and dishes.
Our one bossy female call duck is pretty funny since she will quack very loudly if her flock gets more than a few feet from her. They will then circle back to her.
Also if they aren't making a nest ducks will lay eggs wherever they fucking want. So keep that in mind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4403365
Ours did pretty well nesting, but we never let them hatch since we had enough birds at the time. Only thing to keep in mind is to make sure their area is fairly good size.
When the ground is wet and muddy ducks will bury their beaks in them and look for bugs. Problem is that this will add up and soon their pen will be full of small holes everywhere. Because they are some of the largest ducks if they step in one of those holes they can hurt their legs. Ducks have very fragile legs and larger ones especially.
We have an old drake that hurt his leg and doesn't move much. Honestly surprising he has made it this long.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4415295
>clean food, we don't like scavengers
Not only are the two most popular pets and some of the few animals people default to having empathy prone to scavenging, but both evolved to scavenge even more than their wild ancestors under our care. And by popular I mean the only animals that most people will keep just for company, without being some weirdo outlier. Everything else was a tool or food, closer to a car or a fruit tree than a friend. We are also scavengers, and have all the biological and behavioral traits of a scavenger from now back to when humans first diverged from the other great apes. Humans have no natural hunting behavior or "prey drive", to the point that hunting behavior is PURELY cultural and all instinctive human behaviors are more in line with typical ape socialization, and prefer the taste of meat that has been dried out or "aged" (old but not diseased yet) to fresh flesh.

It is a minor evolutionary feat for a fruit picker to become a carrion picker. Far more likely than a prey-item best described as "giant squirrel" evolving into a natural hunter right off the bat.

humans don't even need their stomach acid to digest food

it's JUST for sterilizing carrion. if you were served fresh meat raw or cooked you would gag for the former or find it low quality for the latter, eating it has to be learned and in one very small population has limited adaptations in its favor, at the cost of their health. if you were offered aged meat ripped off the top of a rotting corpse and cleaned up a little with a sharp-ish rock and a bit of water you would say "thank you for the jerky. this is delicious."

the small amount of meat you need to survive does not suit a hunter either, nor does the human tendency to be a picky eater, but it suits a scavenger-gatherer who will eat some meat, and many other things, and pick and choose what they like from that meat, as they found it, rather than investing energy in killing it. humans used their intelligence to force themselves to be hunters only because finding enough good carrion requires cohabitation with other predators and a bit of luck, and said predators also hunt humans. even then... man takes his fresh meat, ages it to be like an air-dried chunk of corpse, and then cooks it to further decompose it because he abhors fresh meat.

>>4415375
People eat cured/fermented fish all over the world. Aging/fermenting are all essentially spoiling but they are very controlled spoiling made to preserve the food for a longer time. Predators also hide their prey on trees or bury then for later so your scavenger theory is invalid. Humans are generalists, we can eat all sort of animal, plant and fungi so we can thrive in any environment from a mostly plant diet to a mostly seafood diet to a mostly meat diet. We metabolize theobromin in chocolate and caffein have mild effect on us. We are not able to digest cellulose like many specialized herbivores do (with the aid of bacteria) but we can eat a much wider variety than they do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4414174
Sign up to birds of the world. I think it's $40 a year with a first year discount. That is the ultimate resource for everything science knows about every bird species. Some listings are sparse on details because the birds have never been studied but anything common has full info on behaviour, reproduction, migration, evolution, range, plumage, diet, everything, with citations. It's much more in depth than ebird and allaboutbirds. It's all text content but they link to sounds and images.

I would always google stuff and find mixed answers or no clear answer. Google isn't really good for researching birds, it's a niche topic and the algorithm isn't good at translating bird searches into relevant results. BOW solved that for me. There's no app but if you pin the site to your home screen it works fine on mobile.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Here's the link https://birdsoftheworld.org/bow/subscribe

They have a few you can look at for free. It's $49 a year. For me the subscription is worth it, I don't use it every day but when I want to know anything about my birds it has the answer. Or just ask here and if I see the post I'll look it up lol.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Newly hatched cuckoos push the other eggs out of the nest. It's a built in instinct, so the bird that built the nest both thinks it's her child and takes more care of it (more food etc). Not all bird species can tell by looking that a baby bird isn't theirs, they just know it was in their nest so they raise it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4416444
the cuckoos comes back periodically to check on their baby/egg. If the surrogates either removed the egg or something got to the baby the cuckoo will destroy their nest and kill their chicks. I'm guessing this kind of insurance behavior to stop the ones that are wise to their shit from breeding

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

Other brood parasites do it too like cowbirds. I had cowbirds last year, managed to get rid of them and the innocent little chipping sparrows got to raise their own babies for once - they get brood parasitized a LOT.
I also had starlings but I couldn't get them to leave even after shooting a few (which is legal and even encouraged because they're invasive and nest in cavities to the detriment of native birds that need cavities to nest in)

This thread is dedicated to all animals of the reptilia and amphibia classes. Topics include, but are not limited to: geckos, snakes of all kinds, frogs, salamanders, newts, turtles, tortoises, and much more. Before asking a question, do a search on the internet to see if it has been answered
Classifieds for finding breeders and products:
>morphmarket.com
>kingsnake.com
>faunaclassifieds.com
>reptilescanada.com (Canadian breeders)
>caudata.org
Most forums will have a "for sale" section on them, so look for that, especially if you have a specific herp you want. Craigslist can also be a good source for cheap aquariums, and make sure to check for any reptile expos that occur in your area.

When asking a question, make sure to include these details:
>Type and size of animal
>Enclosure dimensions
>Humidity and temperature
>Type of substrate
>The decor you use
>How often you feed
>The type of food you use
>If your animal is wild caught or captive bred
>How often you handle
>Who you bought the animal from

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4413901
Rodents are gregarious and social. You should be housing them in breeder pair+ mixed age grow out groups totalling 4-7 rats (not counting pinkies, fuzzies, and hoppers) in a 4x2x2 enclosure with enough hides that the breeders can be territorial about their litter when the babies are not yet hoppers, without causing them to come into constant conflict with the rest of the rats. Set up modular pipe runs with block off plates inside the hide, so you can remove your feeders at the appropriate time without having to handle them while they are still in the enclosure or tear down hides, and introduce a strange rodent to the enclosure when you replace that pipe section after harvest to distract them from their missing friend.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4414044
it's okay, certainly not as well done as I would have liked. I had to compromise some, they say you learn on your first one and that is 100% true, I could probably whip a new enclosure together in a month's worth of weekends but this one took six times that long, and had to be completely scrapped and redone with different material because my original waterproofing method wasnt waterproof.
If I have a single piece of advice for someone looking to build their own enclosure, it's that if you have a choice between two options, and one is the clearly better choice but it's a little more expensive, go with that one, do NOT cheap out. Pretty much every cost-saving method I tried during the construction came back to bite me in the ass later.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4414303
I spent a fair bit of time and a non-trivial amount of snake wrangling after to take a full picture of the interior and I didnt even attach it.
also, second corollary to the advice on enclosure making - if you're dead set on not buying a pre-made, make a scaled down, feature-complete prototype as a test first and then sell it, or use it for a smaller animal, or donate it to a local shop, or something. Do everything you would need to do in the larger enclosure, that way you make all of your beginner mistakes on one that doesnt matter, and anything unexpected that comes up (thermostat probe access? mounting for your thermometers? Flex seal smells like a chemical plant opened up inside satan's asshole and has to be applied outside or else your entire house will reek for days?) gets identified and addressed before you start for real.

>>4414433
Sure.
1. Keep humidity 60-70% in the tank. Mist once a day around dusk.
2. Your gecko will take some time to settle before he starts eating. Do no panic. Gargs in particular often take a week+ off of eating around shedding time, may eat very little in winter despite tank still being same temperature.
3. Gargs will bask under a low wattage bulb if offered.
4. Don't bug him until he's eating regularly

Off of the top of my head:
Lots of reptiles can see in the UV specturm so it actually provides additional stimulus they would otherwise not get.
Also kind of niche and specific, but not providing UV may cause adverse behavior changes in different environments as well - when clint laidlaw took his tegu outside for the first time it turned from "scaly puppy" to "wild animal" because to the tegu, clint looked like a completely different creature in the sunlight and it was suddenly in a strange place with strangers taking in a whole flood of new sensory information and it freaked the fuck out.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Caudal luring is a thing many vipers do. Young copperheads and cottonmouths have brightly colored tails for this purpose, darkens up as they age. At some point a mutation occurred, became successful.
Lots of snakes shake their tail against things to make a noise as a warning. One had a mutation making their tail scales weird in a way that makes tail shaking more noisy. Common ancestor of rattlesnakes.
In this case, a viper that did caudal luring had a mutation that made their tail scales weird in a way that probably made them look like arthropod legs. Ancestor of this viper.
When a mutation turns out to give a significant survival advantage, it's only a matter of time before it becomes the norm. And by 'time' we're talking orders of magnitude longer than human civilization has existed.
Evolution doesn't decide shit. Shit just happens, and if it works it has a chance of propagating. This doesn't preclude the existence of a creator.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.sub: Ball pythons and other small snakes
posts.com: Thinking of getting one of these fellas. Besides the obvious big cage, heat temp monitor and lamp, and hides and pool, what should I know/get? Do the redditards know shit?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4414562

Keeping a ball python is fairly straight forward. Try to avoid the ones at big box stores. Reptile expos and private breeders are a good option.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4414562
>Do the redditards know shit?
I assume so, they are pretty hardy snakes.

Add a scale to weigh your snake with to your shopping list. You may want to buy a safer heat source than a lamp as well. Also helpful is something large and flat like a dinnerplate or piece of slate or tile that can be placed over the substrate; it’s to put a thawed rodent on (just leave it there for a few hours, ball pythons don’t need to strike at prey and will happily scavenge) to keep the snake from eating a bunch of substrate.

Stuff you should know:
-They can sometimes be fairly shy and picky about eating, but the using the scale to check weight should help you from feeling too anxious and worried about it. They can starve for ages with no risk of dying; mine once escaped and got trapped in a tv stand without food for half a year.
-The condition of its shed skin is a good indicator of if you have too little humidity (a truly accurate hydrometer can be hard to find); the shed should all in one piece, if it’s peeling off in smaller pieces the enclosure is too dry. Soaking the snake will fix this in the short term if it’s bad enough there are stuck bits, make sure the snake can fully submerge itself in its normal water pool as well.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: One big thing is that they are nest raiders in nature and many do enjoy climbing but almost no care sheets/manuals I've seen mention that. Put some sturdy, stable branches and other climbables in there.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4414562
Do the opposite of>>4414856
Expo bps are all inbred to death by morphaggots. My big box bp and corn are lovely, active, handleable, good eaters, growing fast.

Oh and big box stores have great customer service. Reptile stores are like guitar stores. Narcissistic losers who gatekeep you because you don't know what a 66% poss het hypo xanthic ass viper is. They're all Jack Black in High Fidelity. PetSmart rules.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4414955
Your mileage may vary with taking the rodent placed on a tile. I've heard many times of ball pythons that will only eat food left for them in the dark when their owner doesn't watch them, but mine is an absolute retard who will only take food if its very warm and on the tongs. If I accidentally drop it he will sit directly on top of it and look around/at me confused demanding to know where his dinner went. If I leave it it's still there in the morning and I have to throw it out and waste the rat. They are kind of autists about food in general, it's the only real downside to keeping them besides them hiding most of the time. Like the other anon said they should have climbing opportunities, mine comes out to climb at night unless he's got a full belly.

>>4414562
I was initially afraid to add a ballpython to my small collection due to the reasons mentioned here, but is one of my easiest snakes now. Mine strikes like a cobra and never skips a meal. It was also easily trainable with Lori Torrini's method (check her youtube vids). I do have her in an 120x60x50 but the goofball only sits below the water bowl which barely fits. Get a PVC enclosure to keep the humidity stable, glass and some wood enclosure are really poor in keeping humidity in.

posts.com:
There are two ways to look at it.
In terms of common layman English, birds are not considered reptiles. We consider them so divergent from other traditional reptiles (snakes, lizards, crocodilians, turtles) that in terms of non-scientific, everyday life, we put them in a different category to traditional reptiles based on our initial observations. This also part of the foundation for Linnaean taxonomy.
In terms of modern taxonomy, birds are reptiles because excluding them would create a paraphyletic group. Putting crocodilians (fellow archosaurs of birds) in the category of reptiles means you cannot reasonably exclude birds. And the general scientific premise for reptiles is that every amniote past the last common ancestor with Synapsids that isn't a Synapsid is essentially a Sauropsid (Reptilian). We can also notice that some features of birds are highly specialized reptilian features (such as feathers sharing traits to similar structures on pterosaur fossils and certain basal proteins in crocodilian scales), while others (such as endothermy and the loss of teeth for beaks) are the product of convergent evolution that came about for differing reasons (or some similar reasons but different genetic expressions) to those found in other animal groups.

Oftentimes the trap breaks the lower spine, not the neck and causes the little vermin a great deal of pain before it finally dies. It is absolutely necessary to kill them as soon as you can, and in my mind, if you must kill, do it quickly and cleanly as you can. If you can see one, there are probably several you don't see, so keep setting traps until it's been days since you got one. Let me reiterate, it is absolutely imperative that you kill all of them as soon as you can. If you hesitate or show mercy, not only will they fuck your world, you will end up having to kill far far more of them in the future. I am listening to rat scratches in the ceiling right now. >>4396491
My guess is that South American Corvids aren't well suited to the climate/environment of Patagonia. Looking at the "List of birds of Brazil" Wikipedia page, it appears the only Corvids in Brazil belong to the genus Cyanocorax. A large portion of the range in the Corvidae range map seems to be due to the range of the genus Corvus (which makes up 1/3 of Corvid species) and according to its Wikipedia page it occurs "on all temperate continents except South America". Corvus would likely do quite well in temperate SA but it appears that Central America is the barrier preventing them from reaching it (I think Corvus corax is the closest in the Americas but its range stops in Nicaragua).

Sure, maybe. I'm not claiming to know.
Koalas, like wombats, have a backwards-facing pouch -- which is also downwards-facing in the case of the koala.
This is apparently because they descend from a common ancestor that burrowed like a wombat and didn't want dirt in its pouch.
The koala, though, has evolved a sphincter muscle around the top (bottom) of its pouch so that the baby koalas don't fall out 150 feet up a gum tree.

More of an empty feeling, like something is missing, and I'll never have it again. A feeling of regret. Ive had this day dream of us being happy and enjoying life. Our home life kinda sucked ass. But now that will never happen. I will be alone. Unless I clone him. Why shouldn't I? I know the clone won't actually be him, but it will be in a way. Like his son if you will. Why shouldn't I give it the life I wanted to give him? He would be complete, not castrated, not declawed. Would it be fucked up? Would it be fucked up to let him have a family of his own? I miss him terribly. Its crippling. All these years of working to some happy place and he didn't make it. I failed him.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4417179
He isn’t going to act like your old friend at all. Mostly because he isn’t going to have been a stray before meeting you nor will he be declawed or anything, which would absolutely affect his personality.
If you do clone him, you should not in any way pretend that he’s your old friend. He isn’t. He’s a genetically identical cat and that is where the similarities end. He’s a new cat, and his own cat, not who he was cloned from.
Think of it as Big Boss and Solid Snake. Your old cat was Big Boss while the clone would be Solid Snake.
Solid Snake is (for the most part) genetically Big Boss. He’s nothing like Big Boss in any other terms but genetically, though.
If you decide to clone him, do yourself and your cat a favor and treat him like an entirely new cat.
But that in itself is redundant, so you’d be better off and would be more productive in getting yourself a cat like Raiden. i.e. just rescue an entirely different cat in need from a shelter and try to move on.

>>4417584
Much of the time we don't understand a species well enough to know how the ecosystem will respond to its extinction. Conversely, even a species with a major place in its ecosystem may be replaceable. For example, the north american chestnut tree composed most of the forests of north america, but is virtually extinct now. Its niche was successfully replaced by oak (acorn) trees.

Good analogy ive heard is it's like playing Jenga.
Sure you can take some blocks out and things basically keep going.

Better to have redundancies.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4416614
This.
Axolotls are just some random newt from Mexico that would have died out a long time ago had we not payed them any mind. Imagine how much further behind we would be on cloning and regeneration research had they not existed.
The structure of mantis shrimp punchers is so unique that we're studying it to make our materials stronger.
All your silk comes from one species of moth we took a liking to, and black widows and golden weavers make the strongest and most exploitable spider silk.
Penicillin came from some random mold some guy found on bread.

The best non-feels argument for preserving biodiversity is protecting potential future discoveries that could improve our lives immeasurably. Just imagine how many random species that have gone extinct could've had something useful to learn about them.
What if that random fish in Siberia that got killed off by chemical waste dumping had a unique gut microbiome we could have used to make our bodies more receptive to organ transplants without compromising overall immunity?
Now that it's gone, we can never know.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4394215
That complex feathering is probably far beyond the filaments and proto-feathers that actually would have adorned the animal so it would have looked more like a plucked turkey.
>spits acid
We'll probably never be able to know something like that, though maybe the animal's teeth would show the effects of continuous exposure to stomach acid. It probably wouldn't be used as a blinding agent, but there are a number of birds that vomit on themselves or vomit on their attackers as a defensive mechanism. So It might have been possible that Hysilophodon could have used vomit oil in a similar way as Fulmar chicks or it could use a mix of spit and vomit to try and blind animals similar to camels.
Without any evidence of these behaviors in Hypsilophodon I can't really call it accurate, but it's not impossible for it to have used vomit as an anti-predator mechanism.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4400460
You want to qualify these questions:
>What level of nervous system do they have? Unicellular, Cnidarianesque, Molluskesque, Tetrapodesque?
>Are they amorphous or semirigid? If they're amorphous, how do they protect themselves and navigate the world? How do they manipulate the world? Semirigid will have a much easier time here.
>How did they attain intelligence and tool use, and how well-versed in it are they? Are they more intelligent and well-situated for whatever niche they inhabit, or are they really good at using tools but not the biggest brainiac?
My personal recommendation is to go with a cephalopod-esque intelligence and make them deep-sea dwellers that can contort their bodies easily but discovered tool use as an excellent way to preserve them and their kin. You can easily make whalefalls/driftwood equivalents more common on their home world for native materials and a source for them to tread upwards. Bonus: deep-sea dwelling creatures often survive trips to the surface easily, so it would make them look even more blobbish but without any risks to their functionality. It would also give them precedence for wearable devices or containers for respiration or similar so you can move forward with your initial idea if you so choose. Just remember to not make them literal octopus/squids. Try searobins+blobfish as the basis, maybe.

>>4400460
I have an idea though it's evolutionarily dodgy imo.

First off, we have real slime life forms on earth: slime molds. Despite being single celled organisms that don't have anything even close to a brain they're apparently capable of some degree of cognition (see: https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2016/04/160427081533.htm?trendmd-shared=0). Even better for you, they're capable of fusing together into super-cells and apparently can share that knowledge (see: https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2016/12/161221090246.htm)
I hope you're serious about it not being 100% realistic because here's were it gets a little dodgy, lets pretend that enough of them fuse together allows to develop something approaching or even surpassing human intelligence either with this weird cell memory or using millions of cell nuclei as some kind of central nervous system or maybe having some kind of unique organelles to function as a cns. Either way, they're still basically a living puddle of snot so they'd need some kind of powered exoskeleton to do much of interest but I'm not sure how they'd make one in the first place regardless of what their environment is like. Maybe they got some help from some other species and have since gained independence.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>4412299
The semicircular canals are a component of the bony labyrinth that are at right angles from each other. At one end of each of the semicircular canals is a dilated sac called an osseous ampulla, which is more than twice the diameter of the canal. Each ampulla contains an ampullary crest, the crista ampullaris which consists of a thick gelatinous cap called a cupula and many hair cells. The superior and posterior semicircular canals are oriented vertically at right angles to each other. The lateral semicircular canal is about a 30-degree angle from the horizontal plane. The orientations of the canals cause a different canal to be stimulated by movement of the head in different planes, and more than one canal is stimulated at once if the movement is off those planes. The lateral canal detects angular acceleration of the head when the head is turned and the superior and posterior canals detect vertical head movements when the head is moved up or down.[1] When the head changes position, the endolymph in the canals lags behind due to inertia and this acts on the cupula which bends the cilia of the hair cells. The stimulation of the hair cells sends the message to the brain that acceleration is taking place. The ampullae open into the vestibule by five orifices, one of the apertures being common to two of the canals.

Among species of mammals, the size of the semicircular canals is correlated with their type of locomotion. Specifically, species that are agile and have fast, jerky locomotion have larger canals relative to their body size than those that move more cautiously.[2]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I'm getting a cat soon, but do they get really lonely if I'm not around? Should I get two instead?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4408078
If you live alone, and work away from home, then yes it might be a good idea to get a second cat.
Its not much more maintenance than having one cat, mostly just having to scoop and extra litter box or two.
I wish I had adopted a litter mate of my kitten when I got him.
When it is just a cat alone in the house for 8 hours every day they can get bored and depressed which can lead to behavior issues. But if you have two cats they can keep eachother stimulated and active.
If you are going to get a second cat, its best to get litter mates, or introduce them both as kittens since an older cat who is used to being solitary might not appreciate someone new introduced to his territory.

What do you do when flea treatment has stopped working on your cat? I've been alternating Frontline and Advantage which worked really well for a long time but the fleas seem to have developed a resistance to both, and every other flea treatment on the market is worse in comparison. Usually they die off in winter but this time they've just clung on.
She's just constantly covered in fleas and it clearly irritates her. I go over her regularly with a knit comb which removes a lot of them and gives her some relief, but it's only a very temporary measure and it takes a very long time to comb over a whole cat.

She's not picking them up from any external source as she never leaves the house apart from going to the toilet, and she always runs right back in through the cat door as soon as she's done - she's not going off for a little adventure in the undergrowth or down a rabbit burrow or anything.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4406032
My cat looked like this, always reminded me of a panther the way he prowled around.
We had him from a kitten and since the last cat got run over, they decided to make it an indoor only cat. He hated it and escaped as often as he could, every time a door was opened everybody would worry about him sneaking out between legs.
We moved around a few time, for a while we lived on a reasonable block of land and he was free to roam. These were his wild man days. I'm sure he went out raping and pillaging the local flora and fauna. He gained an ear scar and some other injuries in that time, but he was never distressed. Good cat.
The next place we had they built a cage for him outside that connected to the house via a window so he could go out whenever, it had long tunnels and two large sections for him to use as a toilet and to get some direct sun. All up he had over 10 meters of tunnel to run around in, and linked up to the front and rear of the house. He had good times.
I would come home from work at 3 in the morning and he'd play with me. Used to stick his paw under my sisters door and rattle it to wake her up. Great cat, lots of stories.
He died about a month ago, his kidneys were shutting down and he was utterly miserable. Apparently painkillers are hard to give cats, and the kidney meds only gave him two weeks of relief, just time for us to say goodbye and let him pass on.
My all time favorite thing was whenever people were talking he would wander in and either meow at us or just slink up and lean on my leg, wrapping his tail around me. Now sometimes I feel it, either his tail or his body when I stop and talk for too long.
He never came in to my room before, but on his last day he went missing and everybody thought he was dead, nope just curled up on my black bed cover watching me game all day, didn't even notice him until I went to get something from that side of the room.
Soz long post.

>>4409018
eventually it will. unrelated stuff you cared about before that has stopped mattering now will regain its importance after about a fortnight. you'll stop encountering new 'markers' that preceded some habitual interaction you're still anticipating after about a week. you'll stop anticipating those habitual interactions after about a month, by which time a great deal of those 'markers' will have stopped serving as sudden painful reminders and instead reverted back to being the mundane little nothing-tier events, objects, and activities they always used to be. house finally begins to stop feeling so damn weird and wrong and awful around that same time. after about three months the sorrow is a little less sharp, a little less heavy, a little less consuming. eventually the memories will bring with them more happiness than sadness but that's a long way off. for now it's just gonna come and go in waves until it's run its course. (e.g. one day next week you find yourself thinking wow i'm actually handling this much better than i expected to be; then one day next month you start bawling and sob like a babby for half an hour straight.)

I think i have a very loving and affectionate feline.
She lets me pet her belly everyday. She encourage me to rub belly fur, and while i rub it she drools and give me claw massage.
When the year turns from winter to spring, me and her walk outside. She follows me around like a good kitten, while chatting and chirping.
I take good care of her, she gets snacks everyday, food is availeble throughout the house, she has 8 food bowls scattered around the house. But she never got fat, in fact shes 12 years old and hasnt weight over 8 pounds.
After snacking, its clean-up time, and then we head for the door to talk a walk in the big garden, then usually what happens is i get bored and go back inside, then 5-12 hours passes and she calls to be let inside again.
She's the guardian of my area, i have serval neighbors telling me, she often comes for visit at their house and sleep in the bed or sofa.
I think shes having a very good life, and people around here love cats, so me and her are very lucky

posts.com:
I'm tired of the meme that cats perceive their owners as pets, slaves, or subordinates. It's pretty clear from their behavior that they seem to perceive their owners as parents well into adulthood.

Consider that meowing is not a typical form of communication for cats EXCEPT when a kitten is trying to get the attention of its mother. The fact that pet cats predominantly meow to get human attention supports this theory. Additionally, when conducting an attachment behavior test, cats actually scored very high on attachment to their owners, about even compared to dogs and children.
https://www.cell.com/current-biology/fulltext/S0960-9822(19)31086-3?_returnURL=https%3A%2F%2Flinkinghub.elsevier.com%2Fretrieve%2Fpii%2FS0960982219310863%3Fshowall%3Dtrue

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4415130
Its really all a case by case basis. Some cats can be very peculiar, some cats don't give a shit.
Assuming you've raised the cat to be chill and comfortable with being handled it can still have spots where it is over sensitive or ticklish that can cause it to react.
Cats are also prone to over stimulation, if you've ever pet a cat, and he was purring like a motor, and being lovey dovey and then in an instant freaks out and bites or claws with no warning, its because their little brains just can't handle any more and they short circuit.
Some cats also suffer from something called Feline hyperesthesia syndrome where they're so sensitive contact can stressful or even hurt them.
The rule I usually go by is I let the cat tell me where it likes to be pet. When you introduce yourself just kind of hold out your hand a foot in front of their face a little lower than eye level. They'll come up, sniff at your hand, and then usually move their head towards your hand. Some cats brush their cheeks and snoot against your hand, some will go for a headbutt, some want their chin scratch, or they'll body check your hand. If it comes by for another pass you're in good shape.

posts.com:
>>4415568
When you get to the new house with your cat, keep it in one room with all of its stuff, until it gets familiar enough to confidently explore the rest of the house.
Other than bringing all its favorite object/toys with you, put a lot of stuff from the older house in its room in order to surround the cat with the familiar smell as part of a relax therapy.
Keep the place as quiet as possible in the first days, and don't leave the cat for a long time. Try to your old routine (work, food schedule, playtime etc.) to not alienate the cat even more.
