posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4415568
>put cats in kennels
>place kennels out of the way but still in sight of the action
>prop open front door/garage doors
>back door too for nice cross breeze
>begin loading truck
>cats get to see stuff being systematically carted out of the house
>cats not getting underfoot or slinking outside themselves unnoticed
>finish loading, secure doors, release cats, leave, go unload stuff at new house
>return a couple hours later and do it all again
>repeat for however many days
>last day is when you hire moving van to one-shot all the large furniture and remaining big/heavy/boxed stuff
>kennel cats and/or confine to an empty back room if also hiring brofessional movers
>release cats, leave, unload, return, kennel again, take cats to new house
no clue if there's a standard practice, that's just what i've done each time. 3 moves, 3 cats, none long distance. in retrospect: they got time to realize something big was underway and then the unfamiliar new place was already filled with familiar old stuff when they arrived so it maybe only smelled half wrong. in reality: i absolutely would've sprung it on them if Moving Day had ever made more sense than Moving Week, and they would've adjusted.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4415568
Long convoluted story short
>*bought* a house, moving out of a rented condo
>trying to move without family "friend" landlord knowing (despite her living in the other side)

I got the keys and had a week to move, hopefully in small chunks.
I took my 2 cats over with all their stuff as soon as I got keys, in case some confrontation happened.

They tried to hide, but there was nowhere to hide.
Im not exaggerating, after one night I showed up and the cats were laying on their backs in the living room, like kings who owned the place.

I guess since they had nowhere to hide, and there was nothing scary, and it didnt take long to just walk around and smell everything in the house, they got accustomed really quick.
I just locked them with their beds and toys into a room when we would bring in more loads.

They didnt like the commotion, but they didnt seem to be THAT bothered by it, because they were so happy to see us anyways.

So take that for what its worth, I think allowing them to get the lay of the land with little to nor furniture to scare them worked out REALLY well, even though that wasnt the intention.

There are a few stray cats where I live. I don't know where they came from, they were here before I moved to the area. One of them seems to have been close to the previous tenant, it keeps trying to get into my place and most of the time I allow it. I feed and pet it sometimes, though it is quite picky with its food. I don't buy cat food so sometimes when it refuses something I sacrificed from my own food I chase it out. I don't consider it my pet.
A few weeks ago I noticed it has a collar, something it did not have before. I know one neighbour that also takes care of the same cat so I figured she was claiming it, not that I cared. Then one day I get home just as my neighbour takes the cat out. I open the door and the cat darts in. I laugh at it and the neighbour says something. I did not hear what, I was listening to music at the time. I also did not ask what and just ignored her, I can be quite the pos at times. Next time I saw the cat, it did not have a collar anymore.

6mo is puppy teenage phase and they are notoriously hard to handle here. They settle in later but it takes about 2 years for dogs to fully mature, calm down and become sensible. posts.sub: Is a marine tank for small invertebrates feasible for breeding?
posts.com: so I've had a facination with small marine invertebrates like skeleton shrimp, mole crabs, nondiscript species of amphipods, shrimp, and crabs. is it possible to set up a salt water breeding tank? obviously things like crabs will have that larval stage of development so is there even a way to set up a salt water tank without any sort of filter?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4416639
no

your main problem is pumps destroy plankton and skimmers filter them out, but not filtering kills them even faster.

you can easily have a tank with small inverts that aren't breeding though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4416639
just keep brine shrimp. they need nothing but a jar and a bright spot at your window sill

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: don't try to reap the indoor the shrimp farmer bubble

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4416734
so how does not using a filter kill them faster? is it over population or like an excess of nitrogen or some other element? I've only ever had fresh water tanks with a bubbler and did water changes every couple of months.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4416639
Except the shrimp and crabs, you can breed many of the others you mentioned well enough without any sort of filter or air pump. Researching the simplest of livefood cultures should give you plenty of info about what doesn’t work and why.

I’m not sure what conditions are best for skeleton shrimp, since so many species of pods are called skeleton shrimp and some are more territorial and cannibalistic than others. I also have no experience with mole crab husbandry, but I kinda want to try now.

Rearing some species of shrimp and crab larvae gets fickle and weird. Like needing different salinities at different stages or simple things like the babies killing themselves in any corners at the top of a container because water tension is magic like that. Peppermint shrimp adults are kinda big, but they may be a good easy species with multi-stage larvae to practice and experiment with rearing since their babies are about as big as nondescript amphipods and thus big enough to see and collect out of the parent’s tank before they get eaten. Also, they’re big enough larvae to tell when you’re killing them by accident.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4416978
so I'm mainly interested in skeleton shrimp (family carprellidae) but I wouldn't rule out other amphipods or relatives. the problem theres next to literature on keying out species so I have now way of knowing which species is a filter feeder and which is an active predator. so my idea was a 10-20 gal tank with the salinity of the location the individuals were collected put a bubbler in there and hope for the best.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4416992
>so my idea was a 10-20 gal tank with the salinity of the location the individuals were collected put a bubbler in there and hope for the best.
Yeah, that’s probably the best way to go. Collecting plenty of little scuds and tiny prey beforehand will at least tell you if your skeleton shrimp are one of the particularly predatory ones or ambush hunters. You may be able to visually pick out filter feeders since they tend to have way more extra feathery bits on their smaller 2nd antennae.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4417009
now as for the tank itself how often should I do water changes and could I just dump fresh water in to keep it full or will that dilute the salinity?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4417058
Minerals don't evaporate into the air. That should tell you the impact of adding new freshwater to top off without removing any old water.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4417058
You might be able to get away with no water changes (just having at least some macroalgae) if they turn out to be a species that doesn’t really need you adding anything to eat, like the type that scrapes at algae and biofilms. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4411386
easy green and easy carbon may. easy iron you have to be careful with, unless you have plants that like iron (usually stuff that is red or brown) you can feed filamentous algae with it. Easy green is an all in one that will help balance nutrient levels to advantage plants over algae, easy carbon inhibits algae growth which helps plants catch up and start winning the war.

I don't regularly dose easy carbon or iron, only green, but its nice to have a bottle of them around. They never go bad so you can have a bottle last a long ass time. I fertilize pretty infrequently desu so even my easy green lasts about a year with 10 tanks. If you want to get into fertilizer autism you can do better with dry ferts but easy green is pretty much the best you can do with a liquid fertilizer. Flourish is heavily watered down by comparison.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4412195
It's likely you have ye old API master test kit or something similar. They're not that accurate, precise, or sensitive. Rinsing with tap water and letting it air dry is fine.

On the off chance you have better test stuff, reefers who use colorimeters (Hanna) often rinse our cuvettes with RO/DI, then store it in RO/DI (fresh, not the waste water from rinsing). But even then, I've made due with tap water and microfiber cloth wipe-downs and there is no appreciable drift over the almost 300 tests I have done on alkalinity alone with a single Hanna checker.

posts.name: Anonymous

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4411956
Surprised no one commented on the chiller when a few have already sperged out on the heater, however the answer is similar.

There is no good chiller for an aquarium 10 gallons or less, which is what I assume you meant. Either they're not very effective and expensive (NovaTec IceProbe), or REALLY fucking expensive and bigger than the aquarium itself (both commercial and DIY options). Lots of people every summer here also suggest putting bottles of frozen water in your aquarium to cool it down. Unless you have a really, really tiny aquarium and you don't need to cool much for very long, this is generally a retarded suggestion. I've been saying this for at least three years every summer now it comes up: you would have to add A GALLON of frozen water in a 20G tank (or in your case, half a gallon in 10G) to decrease the temperature from like 82F to 80F MOMENTARILY.

It's way more effective just to keep your room at a decent temperature range, and on the plus side, you will be more comfortable. If your tank is otherwise stable, small temperature swings in a lot of common stuff isn't that big a deal. A lot of these fish do live in areas where the water temp will vary quite a bit after all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4412545
You seems to have forgotten the latent heat of freezing. To heat 1g of water you need one calorie but to melt 1g of ice you need almost 80 calories so one gallon of ice would cool down 20 gallons approximately 5°C or around 10F, if you freeze water bottles the heat exchange would be slower so you would reduce the water temperature less for a longer time.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4412545
Agree with this anon
I know nothing about all this chemistry mumbo jumbo, but i do know that ice-bottles dont work in a big aquarium, and its probably hard to control the cooling in a small one ( havent done it in a small so just guessing here ). A rapid temperature drop will be harmful for the fish, so at least it will require a constant monitoring.
Personally, i had more success with evaporation and stacking ice around my canister filter - not very effective but way safer than dumping bottles in the water directly. I have my canister standing in a large plastic box, and i can fill it with cold water and ice. Again, its not exactly very effective, so controlling the room temperature is imo the best way to deal with heat, as other anon suggested.
Cooling pumps are very expensive, and definitely not an option for a small aquarium. Besides, you will have to deal with condensation if your aquarium is way colder than the room temperature - so I presume it will be a huge mess sooner or later.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

you can try installing a stronger blower to blow air across the water surface, the evaporation will cause the water to cool. This is how some older AC systems work and it's also how cooling via sweating works.

Remember when back in middle school biology classes your teacher told you about oviparous, viviparous and the weird third classification of ovoviviparous animals? Guppies and other livebearers are the third type. They lay eggs inside of themselves and keep them there until they hatch.
And this means that they have a crazy high survival rate for offspring. You are eventually going to need to kill them. You can try adding predator, like the other anon mentioned, but you won’t be able to control which fish they eat (might be the prettiest ones) and how many they eat.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4413643
Fairy shrimp lives in temporary puddles. Their lifestyle is to hatch first, grow and lay eggs fast and the eggs won't hatch until the puddle dries and fills again. This way they can take advantage of a relatively predator free environment (Well, triops adopted a similar strategy and they can eat fairy shrimp but aside of few animals it is almost always relatively predator free) while brine shrimp lives in water so salty that no predators can survive there, I had brine shrimp swimming just fine in saturated water, salt crystals were forming in the bottom so they don't have to stop their lifecycle to get away from predators, they live where no predators can live so they can grow and reproduce non-stop.

tl;dr
Farming brine shrimp: huge tanks with super salty water and algae
Farming fairy shrimp: Fill the tank with water, hatch the eggs. Add algae, they grow, lay eggs and die, now you have to dry the eggs so they can hatch when they get hydrated again. It is a shittier more complicated version of water fleas, just breed daphnia or moinas.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4413064
Depends, how new are we talking? What's the plant load, you got a picture? If your plants are rooted in pretty good, then you could do a big water change with a good dose of some 'liquid carbon' stuff, that's actually just algea inhibitor, and kill the lights for 3-4 days. If you got anything that eats algea, it should make quick work of what's left. If not, you will need to manually remove the dead/dying algea with a toothbrush from your plants or trim the leaves depending on the plant.

As for a long term solution, get more plants, especially floaters, and keep your nutrients in check. Start with a small but regular dose on the ferts and only increase it after maybe a month or so when you've established you aren't feeding algea. How often do you do water changes? I'd recommend waiting a few days after a water change before dosing ferts. That's for weekly water changes though. If you do them less frequently, I'd wait a bit longer. Fresh tap water already has some nutrients in it, so take advantage of the free plant food, before you replenish it with ferts.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4414219
For neos, if they're fed and temp is 70+, they'll breed. Sometimes even without those two qualifiers. The key is to get a large enough starting population for generation 2 to have decent numbers, as the first set of shrimp will almost invariably die in the first 3 months, if not the first couple weeks.

Generally neons will eat some babies, but if you have dense moss, large pored volcanic stone, and other hiding places fish can't get but that biofilm can accumulate, then some will generally survive to be big enough to avoid predation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4415586
It can be very easy, but it always seems like people are more attracted to high tech tanks. I've got a buddy with a 10 gallon full of dwarf sag and a big Amazon sword that runs amazingly. He's got it by a window to catch some sun, but also has a cheap LED. He does irregular water changes too, and not exactly big water changes either. It's stocked with some of his cull platys and a khuli, so he only runs a small sponge filter. Very simple but very low maintenance tank. I've never seen algea in it or heard of many problems with it. He always talks about taking it down, but I convince him not too because he doesn't put any real time or effort to maintain it. Really about the balance of everything together that makes it so easy. Once you start getting high tech or premium stuff, you need to adjust to compensate for the extra 'quality'. Like if you get a nicer light, it will be much brighter and probably cause more algea if your plants aren't bumping. You might even need to start fertilizers because your plants are eating all your nutrients and stalling or choking out slower plants. Adding ferts means you'll probably need better flow, so either a better filter or power head....you see how this can snowball from low tech ten gallon to a high tech 40 breeder pretty quick. Just keep things simple and make something you know will thrive. You can always upgrade later....or enable your new addiction by getting another tank. Pic related is one of my more recent tanks, and is low tech. I didn't even want to run a light but got one for free so what the hell. I just do weekly 30-50% changes and sponge cleanings, and feed them, that's really it

It’s very easy. Mine has automated lights and continuous co2 injection at a very low rate and I usually spend days without needing to mess with it at all.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4415586
It would be easier to deal with a 30gal/120L aquarium, but if time is not an issue its father easy.
If money isn’t an issue, why a low tech? And what exactly do you mean by that?
Otherwise, my best basic advice - a thorough planning is the key to success.
List the equipment, read reviews on equipment, read forum discussions on every plant and animal species you are planning to house, make sure everyone can coexist within their optimal water and environment parameters, think ahead when placing aquarium in regards to light, temperature, maintenance access etc. Take into account extreme changes in seasonal temperature if you live in a hot or cold climate, and how it will affect your aquarium. Think about emergency situations - leaking aquarium or pump, diseases, algae infestations.
Some stuff isnt very important, but the more you take into account, the higher chance of success you will have - and less maintenance will be needed.
My current aquarium is very stable after running for over 4 years, and requires minimal interference - fish seem to be healthy and active, and plants are growing well. Very easy to take care for, or rather i can invest as much or as little time in it as i want - it’s very stable at this point regardless.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4415586
It's not hard, but you have to be a little more thoughtful about stock and/or water changes, and the footprint is too small for a lot of fish to show natural, comfortable behavior.

20 gallon long is probably the best "beginning" tank because it offers a sizeable footprint and isn't too deep to be able to reach the bottom with your hand, but also requires you have a stand that can hold 200+lbs indefinitely, which isn't something everyone has handy.

Really though, the hobby isn't hard unless you go for particularly difficult fish. Find some hardy species you like the look of, and then you can just throw a bunch of plants and floaters in there, overfilter it, and only need to change like 25% of the water once a month or so, maybe less if you don't overstock (but who doesn't love a fuck ton of fish).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4415654
>>4415558
Fwiw I've had Amazon swords melt and fail to root - had a trio of ocelot Amazon swords that absolutely wouldn't take to my water, despite having plenty of more fragile stuff take off. Similarly haven't had any luck with tiger lotus bulbs - tried 4 now - but my Crinum has been a beast since day 1.

As other anon said, melt is common, but also you sometimes just get plants that don't make it, whether that's because of changes in parameters, damage in transit from original housing to your tank, or some micromineral in your water that's missing or too concentrated.

Best suggestion for a ton of plants is just throw stuff at the tank and see what sticks. And if you're worried about it in the meantime, throw some anacharis or hornwort in there, I don't think it's possible to kill either of those plants in water that can sustain other life, outside of high salinity water.

>>4415642
NTA but for a heater you absolutely want to get a temp controller (I use inkbird), because heaters are the main point of fatal failure in an aquarium, and the controller will cut the heaters power before it turns your tank to hot soup. Personally I like sicce filters but they're kinda pricey, the air-powered moving bed filters are great, or depending on stock a sponge filter or similar small filter may be enough. If you're looking to add a good number of fish, get a small external canister instead of trying to do 2+ internal filters, it increases water volume and provides way more surface area for the money spent. Also, don't use replaceable cartridges, that shit is a scam, just get a filter and stuff it with k1 micro or similar no-clog biomaterial, and you'll save money and have better water quality.

I just started my own 10g tank a little under a month ago, but if you look at my picture I do have filter going. I only plan to use it to help get everything started and once my test are constant within safe ranges I'll stop using it.

Some tips.
If you get hornwort be prepared for it to shed like a mother fucker. It's a great plant but my God the mess.
Don't make my mistake and get a tall tank. Get one that's the standard shape. My tank is a pain in the ass to replant things if/when they came up.

Have some way to slowly add water to the tank especially at the start. Plants will come out and need replanting.

If you are using any hardscape and need to glue things use it liberally. Don't try to be cheap like me and use only a few dabs.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4415737
Could be any number of things. LFS quarantining fish doesn't mean much. They could be quarantining too short a time, they're likely not sterilizing the quarantine system after use (generally it'll just be a constantly running system), and they most certainly are dumping those fish into old display tanks with other inhabitants, so that any lingering diseases will be passed around. It is not feasible for most LFS to have a really robust quarantine protocol. They just don't have the space, money, or time. Their profit margins are shit already.

In general though, just keep on top of water changes. Better water quality will be more beneficial than General Cure in the vast, vast majority of situations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>4415642
So the issue with small tanks and tech is that a lot of our equipment is the same regardless of whether you have a 10G or 100G tank. For instance, my pressurized CO2 canister + regulator is like 20" tall. It takes significant space. And it is the same thing I would use on a 10G or 100G planted tank. That's not even including the pH controller I use with it (most use a drop checker to check pH and adjust bubbles per second manually, a controller will automatically turn on or shut off the solenoid depending on pH, but it is expensive on top of an already expensive piece of equipment).

You can try to hide it elsewhere, like in the stand usually, but this may be difficult depending on your setup.

Otherwise I think the difficulty with nano tanks is overstated while the maintenance of larger tanks is understated.

If you use RO/DI or distilled water, this isn't a problem. You can make your own distilled water or use a ZeroWater filter if you do not have an RO/DI unit. Having like a 5, 10, or even 20G reservoir hanging precariously above a tank or sump would be... not great. Saltwater is more dense than fresh and these gravity-fed top-off things have been tested in a nano tank with success, though.
